user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_shmem_try_map:
```c
static int metal_shmem_try_map(struct metal_page_size *ps, int fd, size_t size,
			       struct metal_io_region **result)
{
	size_t pages, page, phys_size;
	struct metal_io_region *io;
	metal_phys_addr_t *phys;
	uint8_t *virt;
	void *mem;
	int error;

	size = metal_align_up(size, ps->page_size);
	pages = size / ps->page_size;

	error = metal_map(fd, 0, size, 1, ps->mmap_flags, &mem);
	if (error) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
			  "failed to mmap shmem %ld,0x%x - %s\n",
			  size, ps->mmap_flags, strerror(-error));
		return error;
	}

	error = mlock(mem, size);
	if (error) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING, "failed to mlock shmem - %s\n",
			  strerror(errno));
	}

	phys_size = sizeof(*phys) * pages;
	phys = malloc(phys_size);
	if (!phys) {
		metal_unmap(mem, size);
		return -ENOMEM;
	}

	io = malloc(sizeof(*io));
	if (!io) {
		free(phys);
		metal_unmap(mem, size);
		return -ENOMEM;
	}

	if (_metal.pagemap_fd < 0) {
		phys[0] = 0;
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
		"shmem - failed to get va2pa mapping. use offset as pa.\n");
		metal_io_init(io, mem, phys, size, -1, 0, &metal_shmem_io_ops);
	} else {
		for (virt = mem, page = 0; page < pages; page++) {
			size_t offset = page * ps->page_size;

			error = metal_virt2phys(virt + offset, &phys[page]);
			if (error < 0)
				phys[page] = METAL_BAD_OFFSET;
		}
		metal_io_init(io, mem, phys, size, ps->page_shift, 0,
			&metal_shmem_io_ops);
	}
	*result = io;

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_shmem_try_map:
#define metal_align_up(size, align) metal_align_down((size)+(align)-1,align)
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
...
#define METAL_BAD_OFFSET ((unsignedlong)-1)
...
static const struct metal_io_ops metal_shmem_io_ops = {
	NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, metal_shmem_io_close, NULL, NULL
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no code fragments that are provably unreachable within the scope of this function. Reasoning and checks performed: 

- There are no statements placed after an unconditional return within the same block (each return is immediate and intended). All early returns (on metal_map failure, malloc failures) are conditioned on runtime failures and therefore reachable when those failures occur.
- No infinite loops or constructs that prevent subsequent code from ever executing (the for loop advances page from 0 to pages-1 and is condition-based; if pages==0 the loop is simply skipped — that is a reachable behavior, not unreachable code). 
- No switch statements with cases that can never be reached, or label/goto usage that makes code unreachable. 
- The two alternative branches (if (_metal.pagemap_fd < 0) ... else ...) are both reachable depending on runtime state; neither branch is statically unreachable. 
- The macro-based logging calls (metal_log) expand to conditional execution and are not themselves dead/unreachable code — they simply may perform no action at runtime if the logging handler or level conditions are not met.

Given only this translation unit and without global invariants that would statically force certain conditions (for example, if it were guaranteed that _metal.pagemap_fd is always <0 or always >=0 across the whole project), there are no code fragments inside metal_shmem_try_map that are statically unreachable and therefore no specific fragments to report for MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 investigation.
